content.description: Locate a low angle right facing face with several shallow cracks splitting its face just up and left of a large cairn. Climb these cracks up to a large block and then over a small roof. Move right slightly and continue up on more slightly left slanting cracks to a slabby corner to the summit.
content.location: The low angle right facing face above the cairn at the base of the cliff.

climbs.name: Dividing Line
climbs.fa: Jamie McNeill, Alysia Catalfamo, Jay Harrison

content.description: P1: (5.9) Start up a short slab then up to crack through a small bulge. Then enjoy the great layback and jamming moves up the slightly overhanging left trending flake above.   P2: (5.2) From the ledge climb up the slabby cracks above to the top. Can easily be done in one pitch.
content.protection:
Standard Rack. Is a bit committal above the small slab at the beginning but offers great gear. 

  There is a small tree with a sling around it at the top of the first pitch but you will need to build an anchor or walk off to descend from the top.
content.location: About 60' to the right of Opplevelsen climbing out the left of the cracks ascending the slightly overhanging face.

content.description:
Climb the small slab as for Dividing Line then trend out right and take the right of the slightly overhanging cracks up to the ledge above. 

  Rap from a tree on the ledge or continue to the summit via Dividing Line.
content.protection: Standard rack. Lots of protection to be had but a lack of good stances to place it from.
content.location: The right of the two cracks splitting the overhanging face 60' right of Opplevelsen.

content.description: Climb the vertical hand crack going up between two pine trees. The crack offers perfect jams most of the way. Once the crack ends at a small bulge move slightly right around the bulge and up the cracks to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #3 C4. May want doubles in the #1-#2 C4 range.
content.location: About 50' to the right of Dividing Line go up a very steep wooded gully to a flat area at the base of the cliff. This line climbs the vertical crack between the two pine trees that are about 4 feet apart and right against the cliff.

content.description:
In the original Adirondack Rock book this was called Dartmouth Wall but will be called Sweeper Wall in the newest edition. 

  This wall is the farthest left from a climbers perspective of the Summit cliffs that are seen once you came up from the first big ladder. 

  The cliff faces Southwest and gets sun most of the day. The base of the cliff is heavily wooded and a bit hard to move along. The summit is the top of the mountain and sports beautiful views. 

  The rock is mostly clean but has a very fine rough lichen on it that acts like sand paper on your hands so bring tape! 

  There are a few great climbs here already and many more possibilities.
